Author: amichail
Content: Because they may not fund it if it is not.

Author: ryanr
Content: Great response.  We are in Beta and trying to get everything looking good for our public launch.  We hope to have the FAQ's updated soon and be more descriptive on our front page.  Thanks for the feed-back.

Author: danielha
Content: It's your company. Why would it be an issue whether or not it was secret?

Author: staunch
Content:
"Be Narrow," he said, "Be Tiny." Today, he flat-out admitted "I was working on Odeo at the time I wrote that, and I was ignoring most of those rules."

The difference between knowing something intellectually and actually living it. It's so easy to convince yourself you're following your own rules, even when you're not.

Author: amichail
Content:
To complicate matters, what if your proposal is rejected in this coming round but you are thinking of applying again in the following round?

Clearly, not making a prototype public becomes more of an issue in that case.

Author: amichail
Title: How secret do startup proposals to Y Combinator need to be?  Should applicants avoid making any of their prototypes public?

Author: Alex3917
Content:

Author: danw
Content:
"How often will Justin go to the bathroom today?"

"How many hours will Emmett go without sleep?"

I can see it working, up untill the point the digg users arrive: "When will Justin totally bang a chick?!?"

Author: amichail
Content: Another idea would be to have a prediction market about all sorts of short-term events (e.g., in the next day/week) in Justin's life.\n
